snippet: Amid tense negotiations, Athens invoked a little-used option to defer June payments to the International Monetary Fund until the end of the month.
abstract: Greece invokes little-used option of deferring series of payments on its $335 million debt to International Monetary Fund, along with three other loans, totaling 1.6 billion euros, until end of June; maneuver amplifies pressure on negotiations over economic changes and spending cuts that creditors have demanded ahead of 7.2 billion euro, or $8.06 billion, bailout payment.

byline.original: By NIKI KITSANTONIS and LIZ ALDERMAN
byline.contributor: Niki Kitsantonis reported from Athens and Liz Alderman from Paris. Landon Thomas Jr. contributed reporting from New York and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.

lead_paragraph: Amid tense negotiations, Athens invoked a little-used option to defer June payments to the International Monetary Fund until the end of the month.

headline.main: Tsipras and Greece Buy Time From I.M.F.
headline.print_headline: Greece Defers Debt Payment, Hoping for Progress in Talks
